start.title:
The Moonshot
Exploring the Moon's Lava Tubes with Quadratics
start.description: Using advanced simulations and the power of quadratic functions, you’ll help navigate a lunar probe toward the entrance to a massive moon cave that may one day shelter astronauts, store supplies, and unlock vital resources.

S2_D0_FSQ2_C0.img: The Moon Formation
S2_D0_FSQ2_C0.imgDescription: A giant collision with a planet called Theia created the Moon from scattered debris.
S2_D0_FSQ2_C0.img2: The Birth of the Moon
S2_D0_FSQ2_C0.imgDescription2: Hot rock blasted into space from the impact came together to form the Moon.
S2_D0_FSQ2_C0.img3: From Lava Ball to Lunar Surface
S2_D0_FSQ2_C0.imgDescription3: The Moon cooled from a hot lava world into the solid surface we see today.
S2_D0_FSQ2_C0.img4: How Lava Tubes Are Born
S2_D0_FSQ2_C0.imgDescription4: Cooling lava forms a hard roof while hot lava flows beneath, creating tunnels.
S2_D0_FSQ2_C0.img5: The Four-Step Formation Process
S2_D0_FSQ2_C0.imgDescription5: Lava tubes form when molten lava drains out from beneath a cooled crust.
S2_D0_FSQ2_C0.img6: Inside a Lava Tube System
S2_D0_FSQ2_C0.imgDescription6: Beneath solid rock, lava flows like an underground river creating open spaces.
S2_D0_FSQ2_C0.img7: Lava Tubes Visible from Space
S2_D0_FSQ2_C0.imgDescription7: Collapsed sections reveal the paths of hidden lava tubes from orbit.
S2_D0_FSQ2_C0.img8: A Natural Skylight
S2_D0_FSQ2_C0.imgDescription8: Skylights are collapsed roofs that open into massive underground lava tubes.

S2.S2_D1_FSQ2_C2:
Welcome to the Space Research Center

Beneath the Moon's surface lie vast lava tubes — silent tunnels untouched for billions of years. Scientists believe these hidden chambers could one day shelter astronauts and vital resources, but no one has ever explored them… until now.
S2.S2_D2_FSQ2_C2: Hello Ethan, welcome to your mission briefing. Let’s get started at the very beginning. Are you familiar with how the moon was formed, 4.5 billion years ago?
S2.S2_D3_FSQ2_C1: Something about a massive collision? I'm not sure of the details.
S2.S2_D3_FSQ2_C2: You are right. Two planets, the Earth and a Mars-sized object called Theia collided. The impact was massive. It ejected a massive amount of molten material into space. Over time, this material clumped together and eventually formed our Moon.
S2.S2_D4_FSQ2_C1: Fascinating — does this have anything to do with our mission?
S2.S2_D4_FSQ2_C2: Yes! Because these events helped create a network of caves on the moon—caves where humans might someday create colonies.
S2.S2_D5_FSQ2_C2: You see, the moon wasn’t always the cold, gray world we see today. It used to be a molten ball of lava, glowing like a second sun in Earth's sky.
S2.S2_D6_FSQ2_C1: What, a molten Moon? A giant ball of lava? That's hard to imagine. I'm guessing it cooled down eventually?
S2.S2_D6_FSQ2_C2: It did, but unevenly. Even after it cooled on the surface, it was still molten underneath. In fact, the moon had a lot of volcanos, where the lava would come to the surface. You can still see the evidence today: see those dark patches on the Moon? Those are ancient lava flows.
S2.S2_D7_FSQ2_C1: So the Moon was basically covered in flowing lava rivers?
S2.S2_D7_FSQ2_C2: Yes! And, here’s what’s even more interesting: when those rivers of lava cool down, they often leave behind a network of tunnels. We call them lava tubes.
S2.S2_D8_FSQ2_C1: Lava tubes? You are saying there is a network of lava tunnels under the moon? How do we know that?
S2.S2_D8_FSQ2_C2: On earth, scientists have found that the outer surface of flowing lava cools down first and hardens into solid rock. However, underneath this solid crust, the molten lava keeps flowing— like an underground river. Then, once all this flowing lava drains away, it leaves behind a vast network of hollow lava tubes.
S2.S2_D10_FSQ2_C1: And scientists think this happens on the moon, too?
S2.S2_D10_FSQ2_C2: We know it! We can sometimes see them from telescopes.
S2.S2_D11_FSQ2_C1: But how can you see tunnels on the moon, if they are underground?
S2.S2_D11_FSQ2_C2: Good question! Well, sometimes meteors or moonquakes can collapse the roof of a tunnel. Can you see this here?
S2.S2_D13_FSQ2_C1: Wow, the collapsed roof outlines the shape of the tunnel!
S2.S2_D13_FSQ2_C2: On Earth, lava tubes also sometimes have a collapsed roof. They can be beautiful. We call these Skylights. And that’s the aim of our mission: to shoot a probe into the skylight of a lava tube.
S2.S2_D15_FSQ2_C2: And, because the moon’s gravity is only one sixth of the gravity on earth, the tunnels can get much, much larger than on earth. Some caves may be massive enough to fit entire cities inside.
S2.S2_D16_FSQ2_C1: But why would anyone want to live underground on the moon?
S2.S2_D16_FSQ2_C2: Mostly for protection! The earth’s atmosphere burns up most small meteorites. But on the moon, they would be a deadly hazard. The Earth’s atmosphere also protects us from the cancerous heavy radiation from the sun. Finally, the moon’s surface has a massive temperature: from 250°F in daylight to  -208°F at night! The temperature would be cold in the lunar tunnels, but stable.
S2.S2_D15_FSQ2_C1: Ok, so instead of building an expensive moon colony on the surface of the moon, we could take advantage of the structures that already exist on the moon.
S2.S2_D12_FSQ2_C2: That’s right. There is huge potential. That’s why our mission is to go gather preliminary data about these caves. We’ve designed a moon lander that is fitted with a projectile device that can launch lunar probes into the skylights of nearby lava tubes.
S2.S2_D2_FSQ2_C1: We’re going to shoot the probe? Why not a robot or rover?
S2.S2_D9_FSQ2_C2: With a single device on the lander, we can shoot multiple probes into nearby caves. We can gather far more data this way.

S3.S3_D1_FSQ1_C1: Captain, It feels unreal watching the Moon's surface like this from Earth. I used to dream about exploring it.
S3.S3_D2_FSQ3_C2: You're not alone in that dream, Ethan. But what's fascinating about our mission isn't just the surface—it's what's below.
S3.S3_D3_FSQ1_C1: You're talking about the lava tubes, right? What exactly are those?
S3.S3_D4_FSQ3_C2: When the Moon was formed, it was covered in lava. Over time, the lava flowed and cooled down. The outer layer hardened first, creating a huge network of hollow lava tubes.
S3.S3_D6_FSQ3_C2: That's right! And because the gravity on the Moon is just ⅙ of earth's gravity, some of the caves are enormous – we might be able to build a whole city in some of them.
S3.S3_D7_FSQ1_C1: A city! Wouldn't people want to live on the surface of the Moon?
S3.S3_D8_FSQ3_C2: Since the Moon has no atmosphere, living on the surface will expose people to dangerous radiation. To live on the surface, we'd need to build very thick walls to block the radiation.
S3.S3_D9_FSQ1_C1: Oh, but if we live in the Moon caves, we'd be protected! How do we really know these caves are real if we haven't explored them yet?
S3.S3_D10_FSQ3_C2: Good question! In some places, the roofs of the lunar lava tubes have collapsed, forming “skylights.” These openings can give us access to the vast tunnel system below.

S5_D0_FSQ4_C9.title: Lunar Probe Launch
S5_D0_FSQ4_C9.adjust_slider: Adjust angle and velocity, then launch
S5_D0_FSQ4_C9.target_hit_reset: Target Hit! Reset to try again

help.heading: How to Reach the Cave
help.body:
Adjust Sliders: Use the sliders to modify the probe's Initial Velocity (20-50 ft/s) and Launch Angle (0-90°). Watch how the trajectory updates in real-time.
Set Target: The goal is to hit the red target located at (50, 0).
Launch Probe: Click the "Launch Probe" button to see if the probe hits the target.
Reset: Use the "Reset" button to start over and try new values.

about.heading: How Velocity and Angle Affect Trajectory
about.body:
Velocity: Higher velocity increases both height and distance of the trajectory.
Angle:
• Optimal range at 45°, it perfectly balances horizontal and vertical velocity components hence maximizing the distance traveled
• < 45°: Flatter, longer range
• > 45°: Higher, shorter range
Combined Effect: Velocity and angle together define trajectory shape and target reach.

S5_D0_FSQ4_C9.feedback_short_distance: Not enough power! Try increasing velocity.
S5_D0_FSQ4_C9.feedback_long_distance: Too much power! Try decreasing velocity.
S5_D0_FSQ4_C9.feedback_angle_high: Angle too steep! Try changing the angle.
S5_D0_FSQ4_C9.feedback_adjust_both: Try adjusting both velocity and angle.

S5.S5_D1_FSQ4_C2: Your task is to test out the ballistic trajectory of the probe. For maximum efficiency, our launch system is calibrated to the optimal 45-degree angle.
S5.S5_D3_FSQ4_C2: At 45 degrees, projectiles achieve their maximum range for any given velocity - it's basic physics! Your job is to determine the exact launch velocity needed to hit the skylight at 50 feet.
S5.S5_D4_FSQ4_C1: So I only need to adjust the velocity? That should make the calculation more precise.
S5.S5_D4_FSQ5_C2: Exactly! The launch angle is fixed at 45 degrees. Set the angle to 45, then find the right velocity to hit the target.
S5.S5_D5_FSQ4_C2: Remember, we're on the moon where gravity is much weaker than Earth's. Find the velocity to launch the probe.
S5.S5_D6_FSQ4_C2: Excellent! You found the precise velocity needed. This creates the perfect parabolic arc to reach the skylight.

S6.S5_D4_FSQ4_C2: Congratulations on reaching the skylight! Can you see why we might want a mathematical model instead of trial and error?
S6.S6_D1_FSQ4_C1: Yes, can we calculate the exact trajectory beforehand?
S6.S6_D2_FSQ4_C2: Absolutely. This projectile motion is actually very easy to model with a mathematical equation called a quadratic function.
S6.S6_D4_FSQ4_C2: The standard form of a quadratic function is y = ax2 + bx + c. Each parameter controls a different aspect of our trajectory.

S7_D0_FSQ4_C9.title: Formula for Standard Form
S7_D0_FSQ4_C9.standard_form_formula_ariaLabel: y equals a times x squared plus b times x plus c, where a, b, and c are parameters that control the shape of the parabola
S7_D0_FSQ4_C9.standard_form_subtitle: See how each parameter affects the parabola

S7.S7_D3_FSQ4_C2: Adjusting these will control the path of the probe. For our lunar mission, we need a negative value for the parameter to create a downward arc. Click on the 'a' parameter and try out some different values.
S7.S7_D4_FSQ4_C1: Ok, when a is -0.02, it opens downward, and when it's -0.05, it's steeper but still downward. I can see why we need negative values for our lunar mission! And what about b? How does that affect things?
S7.S7_D5_FSQ4_C2: The b value helps adjust our trajectory. Try different options to see which keeps us safely above the obstacles.
S7.S7_D6_FSQ4_C1: Interesting! When b is positive, the parabola shifts one way, and when it's negative, it shifts the other way. So this controls the horizontal positioning of the peak. And c?
S7.S7_D7_FSQ4_C2: That's our starting height, it sets the y intercept – where we launch the probe from. For this mission, we're starting at ground level, so c will be zero. Try the 'c' parameter to see how it affects the launch point.
S7.S7_D8_FSQ4_C1: Oh, I can see the parabola moving up and down! When c is positive, we start higher up, and when it's negative, we start below ground level.
S7.S7_D9_FSQ4_C2: Perfect! a shapes the curve, b positions it, and c sets our launch point. Now we just need the right combination to hit the target!

help.heading: Guiding the Probe to Cave
help.body:
• Adjust the Sliders:
    • a (Curve Shape): Controls how wide the probe’s path is and whether the parabolic path opens upward or downward
    • b (Shift): Once a is set, b helps determine the vertex of the probe’s path
    • c (Launch Height): Adjusts the probe’s starting height, like the launchpad position
  • Watch the Trajectory: See how the curve adjusts in real-time to aim the probe towards the target.
  • Launch the Probe: Press Start to send the probe on its mission to the cave at (50, 0).
  • Reset for Another Attempt: Use Reset to adjust and try again.

about.heading: Standard form of Quadratic Function
about.body:
The equation y = a x² + b x + c

represents a parabola, a curve that models projectile motion like the path of the lunar probe, where y is the height of the probe in feet at a horizontal distance x feet.


Coefficient Breakdown:
  • a (Opening and Direction): Controls the curve's width and direction
  • b (Shift): Together with a, determines the location of the curve’s vertex (the highest or lowest point)
  • c (Vertical Start - Y-Intercept): Sets the starting height of the curve on the y-axis

S8.S8_D1_FSQ4_C1: Alright, but how do we figure out the exact mathematical model for this trajectory?
S8.S8_D2_FSQ4_C2: Using the standard form: y = ax2 + bx + c. Let's determine each parameter systematically. Since the projectile launches from ground level at (0, 0), what value should c have?
S8.S8_D3_FSQ4_C1: If we're starting at ground level... c should be 0!
S8.S8_D4_FSQ4_C2: Correct! Now, our mission engineers have determined that the b parameter needs to be 1.0.
S8.S8_D5_FSQ4_C1: So if c = 0 and b = 1.0, that leaves only a to determine? One unknown parameter to solve for - that's much cleaner!
S8.S8_D6_FSQ4_C2: That's right! We need to find the value of a that creates a trajectory from (0,0) to (50,0). Remember, a must be negative to create a downward-opening parabola that brings our probe back to ground level. What should a be?
S8.S8_D7_FSQ4_C2: Excellent deduction! You determined that a = -0.02 is the precise value needed. This negative coefficient accounts for lunar gravity's effect on our projectile motion.
S8.S8_D8_FSQ4_C2: With that equation, you created a mathematical model that assured an accurate trajectory.  But there are different forms of quadratic equations that may be easier to control.
S8.S8_D9_FSQ4_C1: Great, because the standard form was kind of a challenge.
S8.S8_D10_FSQ4_C2: The next equation is called the vertex form. Rather than changing the general shape, you can directly control the highest point of the curve—its peak. Let’s dive into it and see how changing the parameters affects the trajectory.

S9_D0_FCH1_C9.title: Vertex Form
S9_D0_FCH1_C9.vertex_form_formula_ariaLabel: y equals a times the quantity x minus h squared plus k, where a, h, and k are parameters that control the shape and position of the parabola
S9_D0_FCH1_C9.vertex_form_subtitle: Explore how different parameter values affect the parabola

S9.S9_D1_FCH1_C2: The vertex form gives us direct control over the peak of the trajectory. In the formula, the parameter a tells us if the curve opens upward or downward, and the value controls how steep the curve is.
S9.S9_D2_FCH2_C2: Try clicking on the 'a' parameter and test values to see this effect.
S9.S9_D3_FCH3_C1: I can see it! When a is -0.02, it opens downward with a gentle curve, and when it's -0.05, it's much steeper but still opens downward.
S9.S9_D5_FCH5_C2: Indeed. And the larger the absolute value of a, the steeper and narrower the curve. A smaller absolute value of a makes the curve wider and gentler. So a is all about the shape, wider or narrower, opening up or down.
S9.S9_D6_FCH6_C2: Now h is the x-coordinate of the vertex, the highest or lowest point of the curve. Click on 'h' and try values to see how it moves the vertex horizontally.
S9.S9_D7_FCH7_C1: Amazing! When h is 25, the vertex moves to the right, and when it's -25, the vertex moves to the left. So h decides where the vertex aligns horizontally. Got it.
S9.S9_D8_FCH8_C2: Next, k. This sets the vertical position of the vertex. It determines how high the probe will fly before descending. Try the 'k' parameter to see how it affects the vertex height.
S9.S9_D9_FCH9_C1: Perfect! When k is 30, the vertex is high up, and when it's -30, the vertex is below the x-axis. So k determines how high the vertex is. Makes sense!
S9.S9_D10_FCH10_C2: That's the power of vertex form! You have direct control over exactly where the peak occurs and how high it goes. This makes mission planning much more precise.

S10_D0_FSQ4_C9.title: Lunar Probe Navigation
S10_D0_FSQ4_C9.heading: Find a Path Between Launch and Landing Points

a.ariaLabel: Adjust a value to control curve steepness

h.ariaLabel: Adjust h value to control horizontal position

k.ariaLabel: Adjust k value to control vertical position

graph.ariaDescription: Graph showing the probe's trajectory path from launch point to target

equation.ariaLabel: Current quadratic equation in vertex form

S10_D0_FSQ4_C9.mission: Mission: Create a trajectory from (0,0) to (50,0) feet

status.perfect: Perfect! Your trajectory successfully connects the launch and landing points!
status.keepAdjusting: Keep adjusting! The trajectory should connect the launch point (0,0) and landing point (50,0) feet.
status.targetBelowLevel: X-intercepts must be (0,0) and (50,0) feet. Adjust the curve to ensure it connects these points.

help.heading: Adjusting the Trajectory
help.body:
1. Adjust the Sliders:
  • Horizontal Shift (h):
    • Controls the horizontal position of the vertex of the probe’s path
    • Increasing h shifts the probe’s path to the right, and decreasing h shifts it to the left
  • Vertical Shift (k):
    • Controls the vertical position of the vertex of the probe’s path
    • Increasing k moves the probe’s path higher, and decreasing k lowers it
2. Watch the curve update in real-time as you adjust the values, ensuring it starts from (0,0) and lands at (50,0).

about.heading: Vertex Form of Quadratic Function
about.body:
The vertex form of a quadratic function is

y = a (x − h)2 + k

, which represents a parabola, a curve that models projectile motion like the path of the lunar probe, where y is the height of the probe in feet at a horizontal distance x feet.
  • h (Horizontal Shift): Moves the parabola left or right. It determines the x-coordinate of the vertex. For example, if h = −3, the parabola shifts 3 feet to the left
  • k (Vertical Shift): Moves the parabola up or down. It sets the y-coordinate of the vertex. For instance, if k = 4, the vertex shifts upwards by 4 feet
  • a (Opening and Shape): Controls the direction and width of the parabola. If a > 0, the parabola opens upward; if a < 0, it opens downward
  • y = height of the probe in feet
  • x = horizontal distance in feet

S10.S10_D1_FSQ4_C2: We need the probe to enter and exit the lunar surface at (0, 0) and (50, 0).
S10.S10_D2_FSQ4_C1: So we need a curve that touches both those points — just like before.
S10.S10_D3_FSQ4_C2: Exactly. In vertex form, we first choose the vertex. The curve must be symmetric, so where should we place it horizontally?
S10.S10_D4_FSQ4_C1: Halfway between 0 and 50… that's 25. So h = 25.
S10.S10_D5_FSQ4_C2: Perfect! Now, our mission engineers have determined that the a parameter needs to be -0.1 for our lunar probe mission.
S10.S10_D6_FSQ4_C1: So a is negative because the parabola opens downward, and it's a small number because we want a wide, gentle curve?
S10.S10_D7_FSQ4_C2: Precisely! That leaves us to find the peak height k that makes our trajectory pass through both launch and target points. Can you find the peak height that creates the perfect trajectory?
S10.S10_D8_FSQ4_C2: Excellent! You found k = 62.5 ft - the perfect peak height for our lunar gravity conditions.

S11.S11_D1_FPS1_C2: So far you've shot the probe using standard and vertex form of quadratic function. Which one did you find more challenging?
S11.S11_D2_FPS2_C1: Hmm, the standard form was a bit tricky at first because I had to think about how a, b, and c worked together. It wasn't immediately clear how the vertex shifted.
S11.S11_D3_FPS3_C2: I agree. The standard form makes it easy to identify the y-intercept of the curve and if it opens up or down but it doesn't directly tell you where the vertex is. What about the vertex form?
S11.S11_D4_FPS4_C1: The vertex form was more intuitive for adjusting the trajectory. Knowing the vertex's exact position made it easier to aim, but getting the right balance between a, h, and k still required some trial and error.
S11.S11_D5_FPS5_C2: Precisely. The vertex form is great for pinpointing the trajectory's peak but let me show a simpler approach.
S11.S11_D6_FPS6_C1: Simpler? I'm all ears, Captain. What's the approach?

S12_D0_FSQ4_C9.title: Probe Trajectory and Quadratic Roots
S12_D0_FSQ4_C9.instruction: Adjust the parabola to pass through both points

controls.aAriaLabel: Adjust the values of Parabola opening
controls.x1AriaLabel: Adjust the values of First x-intercept
controls.x2AriaLabel: Adjust the values of Second x-intercept

feedback.success: Perfect! Your trajectory passes through both required points.

error.invalidTrajectory: Try again. The trajectory must pass through (0,0) and (50,0).
error.needTwoRoots: The trajectory needs two points where y = 0 to launch the probe.

about.heading: Quadratic Function in Factored Form
about.body:
The quadratic function in factored form is a powerful representation used to analyze the roots (x-intercepts) and the overall behavior of a parabola.
f(x) = a (x - x1) (x - x2)
  • Roots (x1, x2): x1 and x2 represent the points where the quadratic function intersects the x-axis (f(x) = 0)
  • Parameter a: Controls the width and direction of the parabola

help.heading: Adjusting the Trajectory
help.body:
1. Adjust the Sliders:
  1. Parabola Opening (a): Controls the width and direction of the parabola.
  2. First Root (x1): Slide to set the starting point of the trajectory at the leftmost end of the path.
  3. Second Root (x2): Slide to position the ending point of the trajectory at the target.
2. Watch the curve update in real-time as you adjust the values, ensuring it starts from (0,0) and lands at (50, 0).

S12.S12_D1_FSQ4_C2: Let me introduce you to another way of modeling the trajectory—using the x-intercepts of the quadratic function.
S12.S12_D2_FSQ4_C1: The x-intercepts? The points where the parabola intersects the x-axis?
S12.S12_D3_FSQ4_C2: And in our model, that’s where the parabola intersects with the ground! By focusing on the x-intercepts, we can directly control where the probe starts and where it lands. The equation in factored form looks like this: y = a(x−x₁)(x−x₂). Here, x₁ is the first x-intercept of the parabola and x₂ is the second.
S12.S12_D4_FSQ4_C1: So I only need to set the starting point and the end point to set the parabola? That’s much easier!
S12.S12_D5_FSQ4_C2: Exactly! It’s the same quadratic math, but in a form that is much easier to control. Let’s try it out with this interactive. Adjust a, x₁, and x₂ to align the probe’s trajectory perfectly with the skylight at (50,0). a lets you control how steep or gentle the curve is.
S12.S12_D7_FSQ4_C2: That's the beauty of the factored form— the roots of the parabola, which define the start and end points.

S13.S13_D1_FSQ3_C1: So, these different forms of the quadratic are like having different tools for different jobs! They describe the same curve, but some are more appropriate for specific situations.
S13.S13_D2_FSQ3_C2: That’s right. And these trajectories aren't just academic exercises, Ethan. They're the foundation for humanity's future on the Moon. The data collected by these probes will guide future explorations of these caves. They may even lead us to discover sources of ice, protected from the burning sun!
S13.S13_D3_FSQ3_C1: Amazing that quadratic equations are such a perfect model for ballistic trajectories.
S13.S13_D4_FSQ3_C2: On Earth, air resistance and wind mean that ballistic trajectories are harder to model. But on the moon, the trajectories are simply parabolic.
S13.S13_D11_FSQ3_C1: Absolutely, Captain. For science, for exploration, for our future among the stars!

quest_completion.subheading: You explored the Moon's Lava Tubes with quadratic equations
quest_completion.content:
You completed your journey through the STEAMQuest!

  • •You discovered how quadratic functions model real-world projectile motion for space exploration
  • •You learned to control trajectory parameters using standard form (y = ax2 + bx + c)
  • •You applied factored form for precise start-to-target trajectory planning
Your mathematical expertise helped chart the course for humanity's future lunar settlements in ancient lava tube sanctuaries!

quadratic_function.definition: Quadratic Functions are second-order polynomial functions which can be written in the standard form y = ax2 + bx + c, where a and b are coefficients and c is a constant, and their graphs are parabolas.

quadratic_functions.definition: Quadratic Functions are second-order polynomial functions which can be written in the standard form y = ax2 + bx + c, where a and b are coefficients and c is a constant, and their graphs are parabolas.

trajectory.definition: Trajectory is the curved path an object follows when it is thrown, launched, or moves through space, often influenced by gravity and other forces.

trajectories.definition: Trajectories are the curved path an object follows when it is thrown, launched, or moves through space, often influenced by gravity and other forces.

skylight.definition: A Skylight in lava tubes is a natural opening in the tube's ceiling that allows light to enter, often created by the collapse of the roof.

skylights.definition: Skylights in lava tubes, are a natural opening in the tube's ceiling that allows light to enter, often created by the collapse of the roof.

probe.definition: A Probe is a small research tool launched from a lunar lander to enter and explore underground lava tubes through narrow openings called skylights. It follows a curved (parabolic) trajectory, which can be modeled using quadratic equations.

lava_tubes.definition: Lava Tubes are natural underground tunnels formed by flowing lava during a volcanic eruption. As the outer layer of lava cools and hardens, hot lava continues to flow beneath the surface. When the flow eventually stops and drains away, it leaves behind a hollow tube-shaped tunnel.

ballistic.definition: Ballistic refers to the motion of projectiles or objects propelled through the air, typically under the influence of gravity and other forces

common.ethan_description: Ethan Kim: Sharp Korean-American Systems Engineer, innovating with modern tech.
common.emma_description: Captain Emma Torres: Veteran Mission Commander, blending expertise with cultural wisdom.
common.bg1_description: Futuristic space center lobby with interactive displays and staff in uniforms.
common.bg2_description: Mission control room with large lunar display and monitoring stations.
common.bg3_description: Lunar base control station with Earth view and technology displays.
common.bg4_description: Space operations center with staff monitoring multiple planetary displays.
common.bg5_description: Team meeting in futuristic control room with holographic terrain display.
